The Reds, who are fifth in National Two South, beat third-placed Chinnor 29-12 for a second win in a row. Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams really led the team from the front. The Reds face seven teams who are below them in the table in their next eight games, as well as league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher believes his side still has a lot of room for improvement.

Nazrul, also called Nazu, allegedly raped a 74-year-old nun. Nazrul, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested at a railway station in Kolkata. The incident caused outrage in India and led to street protests. This marks the sixth arrest in the crime. Police have identified eight suspects in the attack, of which two still remain untraced. All five of the accused arrested earlier have named Nazrul as the person who raped the nun. Nazu had fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage of the attack, and police acted on a tip that he was due to return to Kolkata by train. During the attack in Ranaghat town on 14 March, money was stolen from the convent school and the building ransacked, before the nun was raped in the convent itself.

This interactive video features Robert Opie, the founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, outlining some of the main reasons why we change what we buy. The arrival of the domestic freezer, of washing powder, and of cheaper imports all affected the sort of items on sale and popular among UK consumers. The interactive elements to this video also explore how ownership and ranking of some of the biggest brands in the UK is changing.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked by someone claiming to work for BT on September 15. A woman in Stranraer lost money to a caller claiming to be from BT technical support seven days later. The caller gained remote access to her computer to take the cash. PC Siobhan Pellett is asking people to be very careful when answering a cold call from someone who tries to gain remote access to their computer and to never give out any banking details or account numbers over the telephone.

Duffy, 37, has joined Featherstone on a one-year contract after leaving Swinton Lions. The Scotland assistant coach will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse on Saturday before the upcoming Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy has been replaced by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

On Sunday at 12:50 GMT, the Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were sent to Sker Beach for a horse rider with head injuries. The rider was treated for her injuries and for being very cold before being flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum to a global flight tracking system to improve on the current ground-based radar system. This decision will enable satellites to receive transmissions, known as automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B), allowing "real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world". The disappearance of flight MH370 exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems and prompted Malaysia to urge the ITU to find new ways of transmitting flight data in real-time. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a November 2016 deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines.

Julian Hernandez disappeared when he was five and is now 18, living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and is being held at a jail in Ohio. The FBI received a tip on 30 October that this teenager may be the long-missing child after problems he had applying for college and worked with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm the boy's identity. His mother has been notified of his recovery. His father is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio so he could obtain a driver's licence in 2012 and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. Authorities suspected around the time of the boy's disappearance that his father was possibly the culprit. Mr Hernandez said he was taking his son to pre-school in August 2002 but then fled.

A fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited on Duncan Street on March 2nd caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, according to the fire service. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months and raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, which takes effect on 7 August, subject to any appeal. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia put forward two bills related to the situation in Ukraine, where separatist and pro-Russian feelings are strong in Crimea. One bill would allow a referendum or plea from a territory's leaders to trigger new provisions for a territory to become a "subject" of the Russian Federation, without requiring a treaty with the neighboring state. The other bill would speed up the procedures for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, who would not have to pay a state tax, prove previous residence in Russia, have sufficient funds, or give up their Ukrainian citizenship. The bill is aimed at supporting the fraternal people of Ukraine, especially the Russian-speaking ones and would allow Ukrainians to apply for Russian passports at Russian diplomatic missions before 1 August, and they could become citizens after two months. A Just Russia leader Sergei Mironov announced the plan for the fast-track procedure in Sevastopol. Several Russian MPs have also gone to Crimea.

The McLaren team has fallen from past greatness, now aiming for fourth row grid positions and decent points, despite a history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles. Their slump began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, now compounded by Honda power-unit problems. McLaren achieved significant success with Honda in the past, including a dominant 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. The team experienced further success with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines in 1998-99 but faced scandals in 2007 and 2009. Despite victories up to 2012, titles have been scarce. McLaren's history has been a cycle of triumph and decline, with key figures like Bruce McLaren and Ron Dennis leading the team through various periods. Dennis believes McLaren will overcome their current struggles and break Mercedes' F1 dominance, which is why Alonso returned to the team in 2015.

Tommy Baker, 44, from Everton, was found badly injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27, having been shot in the head and chest. He died later in hospital. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and one aged 32, have been arrested and remain in police custody for questioning. Mr. Baker had left Phoenix Gym at the market shortly before the shooting. Detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour. Police are searching for a silver VW polo that left the scene at speed and are asking people captured on CCTV near the meat market to come forward.

Here are five ways to enjoy Christmas online:
- Everyday Church Online: Virtual services every Sunday for a net-based congregation.
- Guardians of Ancora: A free-to-play fantasy game available on Android, iPhone and Kindle platforms.
- German marketing company Viral.de created The Digital Story of Nativity, which has been viewed almost six million times.
- Next Manga has just launched its work in app and e-book form. The book containing its version of the nativity is called the Manga Messiah.
- Lots of groups are using platforms like Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to connect with their communities.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining the request to take over 250 hectares of common land. Backers have offered around 320 hectares replacement land. The inquiry has heard conflicting accounts from experts over claims the circuit would damage habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales said it was "difficult to conclude" that the replacement land was of equal value, but it was not opposing the development overall. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, before Welsh government ministers have the final say.

On April 1, Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya for suspicion of being homosexual, and at least three were killed. Chechen Muslim clerics said the report insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, and Novaya Gazeta says this is a call for "reprisals against journalists". Ramzan Kadyrov has denied the allegations, and his spokesman said there are no gay people in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is helping people flee Chechnya and accuses Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses.

Investing Solutions received benefit payments over the past two years by finding properties for single homeless men. Fresh Start Housing finds clients from London homeless charities and refers clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. Investing Solutions makes money by putting several unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person. Investing Solutions and Fresh Start are based in the same building and were set up by Samir Patel. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK. One tenant, Nigel McCann, was housed in unsuitable properties. Nearly half the money that Investing Solutions has received over the past two years has been paid by Wandsworth Council.

London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points, while NBA player Ben Gordon added 13. The team was coached by Joe Prunty. Netherlands scored the first 10 points of the fourth quarter to lead 71-60 and held on to win. Worthy De Jong led Netherlands with 18 points. GB now begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary in midweek.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) will debate on August 16th a request from McGregor for an exception to the rule that fights at 154 lbs require 10oz gloves. Mayweather had posted on Instagram that he would be wearing 8oz gloves but had not submitted the necessary waiver document at that stage. The NAC executive director stated that he had never seen a move to 8oz gloves at 154lbs before. The NAC will debate the matter publicly before announcing its decision.

The Sunday Post's London office is closing, marking the end of an era for Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism. Fleet Street was home to numerous national papers and was a pinnacle for journalists. The first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, was published in Fleet Street on 11 March 1702. At its height, 85% of information to the public came through the newspapers. The street was known for its many bars and pubs frequented by journalists. However, media tycoon Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping in 1986, leading to a decline. Most national newspapers had moved away from Fleet Street by 1988. Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, reporters for the Sunday Post, share their experiences of working on Fleet Street during its heyday.

Rowling stated that abusive comments remind her how big the world is and how many more decent people there are than not. She had been called "a traitor" for her political views and had blocked some abusive Twitter users she believed had been supporters of the Scottish National Party (SNP). She also revealed she had "responded to other really nice SNP supporters" and had discussed "how much I had in common politically with many of them".

A University of Edinburgh study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and found children from deprived backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. Poorer young people were about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than their better-off counterparts. Household poverty was identified as an exacerbating factor that increased the likelihood of young people offending. Boys are three times more likely than girls on average to engage in violent acts. Girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime. Another study showed the recent fall in crime rates in Scotland has not benefitted areas with the most chronic rates of crime and that crime tends to be highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods. The Scottish government has said Scotland is becoming a safer place to live.

Mr. Haugh, 25, was stabbed in the Marian estate early Sunday. Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and remanded in custody to appear in court next week. Two other men arrested were released without charge. Mr. Walsh and two males allegedly entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr. Haugh, a fight ensued, and Mr. Haugh received a stab wound to his back. Garda recovered knives and golf clubs at the scene. Mr. Haugh was pronounced dead at 06:00 local time at Limerick University Hospital. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade with blood on it. Mr. Walsh was remanded in custody until August 14.

In May 2014, Phil Flanagan tweeted about Tom Elliott who had appeared on a BBC radio programme. The tweet read "Tom Elliott speaks to Steven Nolan about past. "I wonder if he will reveal how many people he harassed and shot as a member of the UDR." Mr Elliott served in the UDR for 10 years, between 1982 and 1992. The High Court heard that he has a clear MoD record. The tweet was deleted by Mr Flanagan within an hour of being posted. The apology will state that the Sinn Féin MLA accepts that his tweet about Mr Elliott "was untrue and wholly without foundation". Mr Justice Stevens has reserved judgement on the amount of compensation. The insurance firm which indemnifies MLAs at Stormont, has refused to cover Mr Flanagan in respect of any compensation and costs in this case. Mr Elliott said he has been totally vindicated and Phil Flanagan has admitted that the comments he made were totally untrue.

Hawick Knitwear, which employs more than 230 staff, has increased its production of sweaters to meet demand. Production has been boosted by better than expected sales of the Hawick Knitwear-branded range which launched in January. The company was bought by managing director Benny Hartop in November last year. The knitwear firm has increased its production to 9,500 sweaters each week, from about 7,500 last year, to keep up with demand.

Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, last December. Brian Wright, 55, said he had been blinded by the setting sun. He accepted he had struck Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. Mr Wright said he was sorry for what he had done to her and her family. Mrs Blackburn had been on duty in Bedford Road as pupils left school when Mr Wright's VW Golf hit her. The trial continues.

The "Dynamic Mongoose" exercise is a response to the growing threat from Russian submarines, which have increased patrols in the same waters. The German U-boat U33 and its 28 crew members are trying to avoid detection by 10 NATO warships, with the task of taking out the command ship, the USS Vicksburg, and an oil tanker. The exercise involves anti-submarine warfare helicopters, a NATO research vessel, and underwater unmanned vehicles to help track the ocean. The exercise also highlights a significant gap in the UK's defenses due to the lack of maritime patrol aircraft.

United Nations officials say that genocide and ethnic cleansing could envelop South Sudan. Since July, 340,000 people have fled the violence into Uganda. Every day, on average, another 2,500 South Sudanese become refugees because of killing, rape, and the targeting of civilians along ethnic lines. Ethnic violence has dominated the crisis in South Sudan, which began as a dispute between the Dinka President Salva Kiir, and former Vice-President Riek Machar who is Nuer. Uganda is coping with the influx of refugees, but is beginning to struggle with its generous approach. Supplying water to the refugees is a problem, and as many as half the refugees are children.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle on 12 November at York Hall for the English super-middleweight championship. McKenzie became a professional boxer in 2013 and has a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The money for Bridgwater Community Hospital is part of the coalition's £330m investment for new NHS facilities across England. Once built, the new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit and X-ray and space for mobile scanners. The total cost of the project is £33m. Somerset PCT hopes to get the hospital finished by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally injured outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, close to the city centre. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents said he was a member of a family who live close to the scene of the shooting. There have been a number of shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks.

The best known virtual warriors are the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International, all of whom present themselves as independent activists, separate from government-sponsored groups. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, use DDoS attacks and target rebel websites and accounts. Cyber Berkut is an anti-Western group that aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin, focusing on Russia's domestic affairs, but some of its material covers Ukraine.

Tricia Marwick was emotional as Duncan McNeil and Alex Salmond bid farewell to the parliament, as they are standing down as MSPs ahead of the election on May 5th. Salmond repeated his belief that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse" and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood. McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system. Annabel Goldie is also leaving Holyrood.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, will be gathering experiences of residential care from pensioners, their friends, and their families. This evidence will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies, as part of Ms. Rochira's review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. The review will look at factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care home environment. Her team will also speak to care providers, social care staff and public bodies. Mario Kreft, the chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the aims of the review but is disappointed that the commissioner has not included a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

In the year to the end of June 2016, Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group saw pre-tax profit increase by £800,000 to £3.5m, despite turnover falling by £1m to just over £100m. International sales grew over the year. The Turriff-based company manufactures and supplies feeds for the beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors and has a network of 19 shops across Scotland, operating under the Country Store brand.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden. A man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and want to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, and have warned people not to approach him. He is described as white, about 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, said that the IMF's latest reading of the global economy shows a weakening baseline and that we are at a delicate juncture. These comments come after weaker-than-expected trade figures from China. The IMF has already said it is likely it will downgrade its current forecast of 3.4% for global growth when it next releases its economic predictions in April.

The council held a meeting to discuss problems with the new ferry, which has broken down, run aground, and been suspended since launching on May 14. The Cowes crossing will be free until July 2. The council ordered a review of the project by auditors. Businesses are suffering losses and want compensation. The council is discussing compensation and authorized ramp extensions to resolve vehicle damage. Groundings were resolved as a seamanship issue.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models in London, an international temp agency, is under fire for discriminatory job adverts specifying looks and physical attributes. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners have criticised the agency's hiring practices as unlawful, demeaning, and reminiscent of the 1970s. An employment lawyer stated that the adverts were "clearly unlawful" and could be challenged, potentially leading to unlimited compensation claims. Matching Models defends its practices by stating that looks are important to their clients. The EHRC stated that first impressions count, but the important stuff is not about your hair color and that they should act like a business in the 21st Century.

The shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, was working as an office assistant in the school. Mahesh is alleged to have shot Gautami in the head with a pistol on Tuesday evening and then shot another student, Sirisha, who suffered severe injuries. He was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded until 12 April.

Glaad counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters in shows seen or to be shown between June 2016 and May 2017. The number of transgender characters has risen from seven to 16 this year. More than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. Millions of pounds of public money loaned to Northampton Town FC appeared to have vanished. Mr. Mackintosh was criticised over the loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council when he was leader. About £10.25m of that money is now missing and the loan is subject to a police investigation. Mr Mackintosh had previously said he intended to stand for re-election, but now feels it is the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

Roy Oliver, 37, fired a rifle into a car driving away from a party in Balch Springs in April, killing Jordan Edwards, 15. The policeman was sacked a few days later for policy violations. Roy Oliver was charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. He faces five to 99 years in prison on the murder charge. He is currently free on bail.

Melania Trump and her son Barron will move to Washington after Barron finishes school, but the exact date is unknown. This decision has sparked criticism on social media, though transition spokesman Jason Miller says the Trumps are excited about their new role. There are only two other First Ladies in history who have not lived in the White House: Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. However, some support Mrs. Trump's decision, stating that it is responsible parenting. William Seale, a White House Historical Association historian, said that it is not unusual for children to stay back to finish school. In the past, First Ladies such as Frances Folsom Cleveland only lived in the White House during social season. The role of the First Lady is ceremonial, but more recently they have sought out causes to support and promote. Melania Trump is interested in tackling cyber-bullying. It is possible that Ivanka Trump could take on some of the First Lady's responsibilities.

Pirc has been asked to scrutinise the initial police response to a call from a 72-year-old man who was later found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October this year. The COPFS has instructed the Pirc to undertake an investigation and a report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the COPFS in due course. Police Scotland said it was "fully engaging" with the investigation and awaited its findings.

A yellow wind warning was issued, with gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) possible, especially west of the mountains. The easterly direction of the winds could increase their impact, and travel disruption is expected. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing Telford Road, which is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants won their game against the Panthers, with the final score being 4-3. The teams will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

World champion Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and did five pit stops. Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel came second despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. The race was shaped by an incident-packed opening, with a number of collisions on the first lap leading to the introduction of the safety car on lap four. Ricciardo suffered a left-rear puncture on lap three, allowing the Mercedes to pass. Rosberg drove off into the distance. Hamilton had done three stops within the first six laps and he was lying third from last at the restart.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, in an interview, said he was coming out to advance discussion of a topic that was "simply ignored" in German football. He is the most prominent footballer to publicly reveal his homosexuality. His announcement was met with praise and support from former teammates, leading figures in German football administration, and politicians. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, which like England has struggled with the problem of homophobia in football.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season to help Brighton achieve promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. Sidwell's contract is due to expire at the end of the campaign, and he is hoping to sign a new deal. Sidwell made 19 appearances for Albion on loan from Stoke during 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal with Brighton in June 2016.

Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool in the 12th minute, and Kurtis Guthrie scored for Colchester. Sean Murray of Colchester United was shown a straight red card in injury time for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

The 29-year-old Reid made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season. He could debut for the U's in Wednesday's EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

PC Keith Palmer's murder prompted the UK Police Memorial Trust to appeal for £1.5m towards the construction of a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum. The memorial is set to bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff and is expected to be completed by 2019. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. The next league game is the derby against Manchester City and Man Utd have eight matches remaining to better Chelsea's record 95-point haul in 2005. Ferguson will make changes for Monday's FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea after seeing Rafael and Anderson suffer injuries at Sunderland, while goalkeeper David De Gea also suffered a knock. Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez will be available for the game at Chelsea.

Mr. Schmidt told the BBC that Google did what was "legally required" to pay the right amount of taxes and that it is up to the government to change its tax system if it wants companies to pay more taxes. Google paid Â£10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. Margaret Hodge suggested a new committee should be established to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms. European Union leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities" to monitor the situation. Mr. Schmidt has previously argued that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where it conducts economic activity and takes risks, rather than where products are consumed and has also called for a debate on international tax reform.

NHS Improvement wants more progress in reducing the NHS agency bill, which had a target of being reduced by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap was introduced in October, which has so far saved £600m. The latest accounts suggested NHS trusts were 10% down on where they wanted to be. NHS Improvement will start publishing "league tables" of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending later this year. Information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust would also be collected.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a symbol of commerce, now represents the end of the Celtic Tiger and Ireland's economic downturn. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien, are starting to see a turnaround, but more needs to be done. Fianna FÃ¡il criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, suggesting investment in broadband instead of water meters. The government highlights Center Parcs' planned tourism development in Ballymahon, which could employ about 1,000 people, but local traders believe that issues such as parking charges need to be addressed to further boost local business.

The competition finishes on 29 May in the same stadium. Eight teams are taking part, facing each other twice, with the top four sides qualifying for the play-offs. Four current or former England players will take part in the tournament: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings and Kevin Pietersen. You can keep up to date with all the scores, fixtures and results with BBC Sport.

Since 2013, the number of plastic carrier bags has gone up by 200 million. From October, people in England will have to pay 5p for plastic bags to encourage reuse. Supermarkets in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland charge for carrier bags and have seen a decrease in bags used.

On Friday, a school roof was damaged, and hundreds of homes in Wales had power cuts following a yellow wind warning. There were train delays and restrictions on major bridges. Irish Ferries cancelled six sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, and Arriva Trains Wales warned of possible delays. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge were lifted in the evening, but Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip was postponed to December 27 due to a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend.

Jordan said he was "super excited" to work with Ryan Coogler again on Black Panther and wants "to put a different spin on it". He also said he could not wait to work with Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. Black Panther will be released in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is hoped to be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. If successful in raising funds it is hoped the theatre will reopen in 2018. The theatre and studios form part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) is contributing £18.8m towards the project, while Haringey Council is contributing £6.8m. The entire east wing will be refurbished at a cost of £26.6m. Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust have committed to raising the final £1m by summer 2017.

James Milner, age 30, played for England 61 times after his debut in 2009. He was in two World Cups and two European Championships, only playing three minutes at Euro 2016. He is the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps after his first appearance in 2004. He scored one international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, escaped a house fire, started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, thanks to her son David, who noticed the flames. The house was destroyed, and their pets died, but the community is supporting them with donations.

An energy drinks giant was considering a £200m offer for West Ham, which Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010 valuing the club at £105m. Since August's move to London Stadium, West Ham have been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups.

The awards ceremony in Los Angeles included fan-voted awards like best kiss and best shirtless performance. The night's big winner was The Fault in Our Stars, which won best movie. Shailene Woodley also picked up best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss for a scene with Ansel Elgort. Other winners included Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart brought his kids on stage to accept the comedic genius award. Robert Downey Jr brought his fellow Avengers stars to their knees while accepting the Generation Award. Clips from the upcoming Pitch Perfect sequel, Judd Apatow's latest comedy Trainwreck and Marvel's new film Ultron were shown.

Smith, 21, was loaned to United in July and has five goals this season. He debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances. Jack Ross said Smith is a really good player and a good fit for St Mirren. St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.
Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to fill in 145 potholes each day for the next four months. Extra staff will repair drainage systems and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group employees were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland. The workers were removing a piece of pipework during planned shutdown activities. According to rigging supervisor Steve Innes, the workers were not provided proper PPE and now face cancer fears. EnQuest said "additional precautionary steps" have been taken and Wood Group said it was committed to employee safety. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was made aware of the incident but no investigation has been carried out.

In 2007, the Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 (£420,000) from New York dealer Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The allegations came to light during a 2012 court case against the firm for trafficking antiquities. The sculpture is thought to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu in southern India. The decision to return the item came after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), who submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May. It was one of 30 objects ACM bought from the art dealer, and the museum will take legal action to get compensation for the apparent fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 quake struck 35km north of Lucca at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake struck at 15:48 (14:48 GMT), with its epicentre in Garfagnana. Several aftershocks of lower magnitude were felt across a large area. Phone lines were down and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution. In Milan, top floors of tall office blocks shook and the quake was also felt in the cities of Bologna and Modena. In Lucca, people poured out into the streets. Alessandro Amato of the INGV described it as a classic earthquake for the area - "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow".
Austin Grant from Sheffield, who was initially doubtful about South Yorkshire's climate, has successfully grown a fruit that is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar announced that the release of their game has been delayed until 24 March, as it requires a few extra weeks of testing. Online heists are coming to consoles before the PC release date. Screenshots from the PC version have been released, with Rockstar promising "even greater levels of detail". Minimum specifications required to run the game on PC have also been published. Grand Theft Auto V became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever when it was released on 17 September 2013.

The 76-year-old artist won the Â£25,000 prize for Squint (19) at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The artist, who was shortlisted in 1991 and has been on the longlist three times, said winning was "very nice indeed". Squint (19) depicts a leper squint, which are "holes made in the sides of medieval churches so the undesirables could look through to the service". The artist said the prize money would be spent on art supplies. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize was established in 1957 and is one of Britain's oldest art awards.

The offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, which support the governing AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, were attacked early on Thursday. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, and firefighters extinguished the blaze. Windows in both buildings were shattered by gunfire, and numerous spent bullet casings were found at both scenes. Police are hunting the assailants, and no group has claimed responsibility.

A 24-year-old who was under contract with the Stags will join Marcus Bignot's side on a free transfer. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. The ex-Burton player will officially join on 1 January and becomes Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Wenger has been linked to a job that Southgate took over in September. Southgate, who oversaw England's 2-0 win against Malta as well the disappointing 0-0 draw with Slovenia, has a World Cup qualifier against Scotland at Wembley on 11 November and a friendly against Spain four days later to persuade the Football Association to give him the job on a permanent basis. Wenger said Southgate "has accumulated experiences and is a good observer of what's going on in the national team," and that Southgate has a good opportunity to show he has the quality. Wenger also said that 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin would be offered a new contract by the club. Midfielder Aaron Ramsey, 25, will miss "one or two" more games.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police is carrying out a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive and the company is cooperating fully with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay, where some workers were allegedly paid less than Â£4 an hour. The charter change will see contracted out services return to operator Serco Northlink from next month. The freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay have been operated by Seatruck, which is contracted to run the service by Serco Northlink. Seatruck argued the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew, many of whom are non-UK residents, but Serco Northlink offered to bridge the pay gap. The new arrangements will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink was awarded the six-year Â£243m Northern Isles contract in 2012.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after an incident at Rockley Park. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother. Mrs. Mitchell and Mr. Dickie had been in a relationship for several years. Mr. Mitchell accompanied his mother and Mr. Dickie to the holiday park bar on 7 May. The two men had a confrontation outside and were separated by members of the public. Mr. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault. He and his mother, Samantha, 57, also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying about the course of events. The pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton died in London at 66 after battling cancer, according to Jon Platt of Warner/Chappell music publishing. Temperton wrote hits like "Off The Wall", "Baby Be Mine", and "Boogie Nights". He was nicknamed The Invisible Man. Temperton traced his songwriting ability back to listening to Radio Luxembourg in his crib. He joined Heatwave in the 1970s and wrote hits like "Boogie Nights". He penned three songs for Michael Jackson's "Off The Wall" and three more for "Thriller". Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. His family requests privacy.

A team including Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon. The function of the more than 450 geometrical "geoglyphs" is still little understood, but researchers believe they were used sporadically as ritual gathering places. Research indicates a wide variety of plant species spread over 6,000 years, which could only have been artificially brought together by humans. Instead of burning large tracts of forest, people transformed their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees such as palms, likening it to a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products.

Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, beat Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes to progress to the second round. Kyrgios said he was tired from his success in Japan and the travelling. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst.

The HPV jab will protect against head and neck cancers. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 receive the vaccine to protect them against cervical cancer. Charities and organizations will deliver a letter to the Welsh government calling for the vaccination to be rolled out, as head and neck cancer cases are increasing. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation. In 2008, a vaccination programme was rolled out in schools and 85% of girls in Wales have been vaccinated.

Jak Trueman, 15, was suffering from a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma and has died. He briefly attended a school prom held in his honour. Since being diagnosed with cancer last August, Jak had been posting updates on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey. The Jak's Journey page attracted more than 28,000 Likes. On 23 January, Jak and his family found out from doctors that his cancer had spread throughout his body and medics decided to not pursue any other treatment.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 with a late goal by El Said, assisted by Salah. An earlier goal by Uganda's Ochaya was disallowed for offside. Egypt will play Ghana next, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for a new railway station, following a study by Network Rail. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans for Skelmersdale to get two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The council will now start acquiring the relevant land. Skelmersdale is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without a railway station.
During a warehouse search near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, plants were found in an "elaborate grow house". A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

- A 28-year-old woman was found with serious injuries in Hamelin.
- Police say she had been dragged by the neck through several streets.
- Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, handed himself in to authorities.
- Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin.
- The motive is not yet clear.

The study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, which looked at 4,600 workers, found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but men are 25% more likely to get one when they ask. The research concluded there was no evidence that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. The study also found differences according to age, with women and men under 40 both asking for and receiving pay rises at the same rate.

Oxford City Council said money had mostly been used for "ground investigations of possible sites" but nowhere suitable had been found. Two cemeteries still have space, in Wolvercote and Botley, but they are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council said it was "still exploring options". All council-owned sites have had to be discounted due to size, ground conditions, a high water table, or a covenant restricting the use of the site. After the two remaining cemeteries are full only the reopening of family plots, the use of a few reserved plots, and the interment of ashes would be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, HebCelt, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will allow visitors to use an app to trigger online information from signs and posters. Videos and band interviews will be available to view on phones and tablets. The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean are among this year's acts. The app will allow people around the world to interact with the festival, access information and interviews, buy tickets and get a taste of the festival.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, which had seen him over-heat and "wobble" on his feet. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime". Many Clouds received treatment for a tendency to 'overheat', but he soon recovered, and his welfare was closely monitored by the authorities as a result.

In the autumn of 2004, a 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage. The defendant, now 34 and called Davina, denied the charge and will be sentenced on 4 March. Judge Ian Pearson remanded her into custody and said it was likely she would be held at a male prison in Winchester. The court heard that Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted to commit suicide last summer. Portsmouth Crown Court was told she raped the teenager while two others were asleep in the garage. In 2014 Ayrton told a worker at the care home where she lived in Fordingbridge, Hampshire, about the attack.

Serbians lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares 6-4, 6-4 in Rio. This loss occurred a day after Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Juan Martin del Potro. Previously, Djokovic lost to American Sam Querrey in the third round at Wimbledon in July. Before the Olympics, he claimed his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

More than 20 competitors are due to take part in Saturday's event in Carrbridge in the Cairngorms. Carvers from Scotland, England, Ireland as well as continental Europe, Canada and the US regularly enter the competition. They can use only chainsaws to carve logs into the shapes of animals and people. Last year's winner Pete Bowsher, from Moffat, is to return to defend the title, and retain the first place winner's prize the Claymore Trophy.

Webb is close to returning from a foot injury suffered in September. He hopes to be fit for the Six Nations in February and has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers. Wales begin their Six Nations campaign away to Ireland in Dublin on Sunday, 7 February.

On Tuesday morning, border agents near Sumas, Washington, encountered two men smuggling ecstasy from Canada. One man, Jeffrey Laviolette, was taken into custody, while the other, Nathan Hall, fired a weapon and fled. Hall was later arrested in British Columbia. The backpacks contained 58lb of ecstasy. Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert were also arrested for planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco; Lambert was to be paid $11,000. The three in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is known for smuggling.

In the past year, Childline counselled more than 4,500 children, compared to about 2,400 in 2011-12, with some children as young as seven reporting torment and abuse. Childline's president Dame Esther Rantzen said the figures should be a wake-up call and that cyber-bullying can follow children home until it becomes a persecution they cannot escape. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week which is coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance.

Ahead of a speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by US Secretary of State John Kerry, a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in settlements was postponed at the request of Benjamin Netanyahu's office. This follows a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Mr. Netanyahu. The US chose not to veto the resolution, which states that the establishment of settlements "has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law." Mr. Kerry is expected to lay out his vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict.

The Queen's 90th birthday was marked by a BBC interview with Prince William, who praised her as a "guiding example" of a good monarch. A picture of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George was released for stamps to mark the occasion. The Queen, accompanied by the Duke of Edinburgh, visited Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and Alexandra Gardens, where she met with staff, viewed an exhibition, and attended a ceremony to open a new bandstand. Political leaders, including Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, expressed their well wishes. Prince William addressed criticisms about his commitment to royal duty, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but is finding his own way. Ten stamps were released to celebrate the Queen's birthday, featuring various aspects of her life. On her actual birthday, the Queen and Prince Philip will unveil a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway, and in the evening, she will light a beacon, initiating a series of beacon lightings across the UK and the world. US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle on Friday. The article also mentions criticism from Republic, who said the BBC had failed to report the birthday in a fair manner.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in their EFL Cup match. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored the goals for West Ham in the first half. The two sides' only previous meeting came at the same stage of this competition four years ago, resulting in a narrow 2-1 win for Hammers at their old home Upton Park. Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup before Thursday's third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, 36, died in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Andreas Werner, 46, caused the crash by turning his VW Transporter right and failing to spot the motorcyclist. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and was fined Â£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to be jailed. Werner was remorseful and could offer no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, left the UK last January and went to Syria where he became a member of Rayat al Tawheed. Khawaja was involved in appeals for donations, video diaries of their lives and "through the keyhole" tours of fighters' quarters. He faked his own death and attempted to return to the UK, but was arrested. He has admitted to four offenses and is considered a dangerous man.
Kayden Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances last season for Wrexham. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season, after turning down a contract offer from Wrexham.

Bottles started arriving at Poldhu Cove and National Trust volunteers have been clearing them away as they are said to pose a risk to wildlife. The National Trust believes a container went overboard from a ship during the stormy weather. It is thought the vessel lost the container near Land's End in May. Other nearby coves have also been affected. Cornwall Wildlife Trust said it was "highly concerned" about the impact on "sensitive marine life". Cornwall Council and partners will be monitoring beaches in the area. The public is advised to keep children and dogs at a safe distance from the bottles and no attempt should be made to recover the bottles.

At approximately 14:00, an incident occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness. Several people received minor injuries in the crash. The road was closed, and diversions were put in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland said inquiries into the incident were ongoing.

Dervite, 28, made 14 appearances last season to help Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite follows David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan in signing new contracts with Bolton, following their promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being prepared to "concede everything", and Labour responded that the Lib Dems were giving people "false hope". The two parties had teamed up to inflict defeats on the government concerning the rights of EU citizens and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but that co-operation ended when MPs rejected those amendments. A Labour source said it was "fairly obvious grandstanding" by the Lib Dems, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of "waving through the government's plans". According to a Labour source there will be "residual tensions" between the parties.

In the current election, defense is a low priority for most political parties, with opinion polls showing it outside the top 10 of electorate concerns. Despite agreement that the world is becoming more dangerous, the UK, like most European nations, has been making significant cuts to its armed forces. The UK military has capability gaps and relies on allies for certain tasks. The UK has fallen to sixth place in global defense spending. Most parties are not committed to spending 2% of the nation's wealth on defense, and further cuts are likely. While the Conservatives and UKIP are committed to renewing Britain's nuclear deterrent, Labour and the Liberal Democrats have different approaches. The UK will have two new aircraft carriers, but there are concerns about manning levels and equipment.

Barcelona insisted they had not committed any offence in the signing of Neymar. They paid £48.6m for Neymar in the summer, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. Between the initial fee, signing-on fee, wages, agents fees and tax payment, Neymar will have cost the club £106.8m. Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money and is being investigated. Barcelona said they had paid 57m euros (£48.6m) for Neymar, but it has been alleged that the actual cost was far greater. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. FC Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to defend the club's reputation. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, died when the van he was a passenger in was hit by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving the wrong way on the motorway. Mr. Luciw's family said retired people should undergo regular driving tests, while Age UK said it was "vital" older people could drive for as long as possible. The accident happened at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire. Currently drivers over 70 in the UK must fill in a self-assessment form every three years to renew their licences, but the DVLA said it had no plans to restrict licensing on the basis of age.

Following concerns about the safety of mesh implants used to treat incontinence, Alison Britton will examine the final report after two patients quit the original review group in protest. The report concluded the procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse, patients should be offered a range of treatments, and reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. These recommendations will continue to be implemented. Tracey Gillies, chairwoman of the independent review, apologized for failing to unite all panel members around the review's final report. Two members quit the review group earlier this year, and it emerged that a consultant also quit the expert group over concerns about the final draft of the report. Over the past 20 years, more than 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants but some have suffered painful and debilitating complications, and more than 400 women are taking legal action.

Muir, 23, broke McColgan's 25-year-old record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan raised concerns about whether Muir's race had met all the criteria set by UK Athletics for record-breaking attempts because it was a mixed 3K race where all the other girls ran 3K and it was only Laura who finished the 5K. British Athletics confirmed Muir's time was expected to be classified as official. McColgan said Muir had what it took to win world medals and that Muir's race had been similar to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago. McColgan said it was a bonus that her record was beaten by a fellow Scot.

Jung, riding Sam as a late replacement, won gold, Astier Nicolas took silver, and Phillip Dutton won bronze. William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after a faultless performance in the show-jumping phase, but his medal bid was ruined by his cross-country performance. Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also encourages readers to meet Henry the mechanical horse at Team GB fan parks and subscribe to the BBC Sport newsletter.

Andy Murray beat Fabio Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5 to reach the last 16 for the 11th time, with match point clinched at 20:57 BST. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Johanna Konta reached the second week for the first time.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found people at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, were charged with allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge ordered the bar's closure for three months. Ms. O'Neill was fined £3,000, and Mr. Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt launched the party's manifesto, saying, "Domination doesn't work, partnership does." Ulster Unionists want the election to be a referendum on how the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle was handled, but the focus has turned to Mr. Nesbitt's comments. Mr. Nesbitt said he wouldn't withdraw a word of what he said and was thinking of what would happen after the election. He said if they are going into Stormont Castle, it will be with a nationalist party, and he would rather go in with the SDLP than Sinn FÃ©in. The manifesto, entitled 'Real Partnership', includes calls for action in tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers to 7,500, prioritising the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community and "guaranteeing" that no group is worse off because of Brexit. The party calls for action on "incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption"

Justice Minister Claire Sugden confirmed a motion will go before the assembly for approval to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales, where plans for automatic pardons were announced last month. The motion is expected to contain the same provisions and allow for pardons both posthumously as well as for living gay and bisexual men. The motion will now go forward for consideration by the assembly.

Laura Muir, 23, finished second behind Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12, breaking Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record of 4:22.60. Muir now holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records and hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham from 24 to 26 June.
Here are some of your pictures from the 26 beaches ranked as Scotland's "most excellent" for water quality.

According to Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC, the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot to kill Mr. Litvinenko, who UK officials believe was poisoned in London in 2006 by Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, who deny any wrongdoing. Mr. Litvinenko drank tea containing a fatal dose of radioactive substance polonium-210 during a meeting with the two suspects and died in hospital nearly three weeks later. Mr. Horwell said the suspects left a "trail of polonium" behind and they had "no credible answer" to the scientific evidence against them. Attempts to extradite the two men have failed and they remain in Russia.

Steve Smith, 26, will captain the Twenty20 team in the absence of the injured Aaron Finch and has been appointed captain on an ongoing basis. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain. Clarke, 34, decided to retire after his side surrendered the Ashes. Smith had already captained the side in three Tests against India last summer. Smith has played in 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches that follow the final Ashes Test at the Oval, which starts on 20 August.

Mr. Farron refused to answer whether he believed homosexual sex was a sin, but told the BBC he was "passionate about LGBT-plus rights" and defending equal marriage would be "at the top of my agenda". He also said he wanted to extend the marital rights of transgender people. Mr. Farron said he voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 because of concerns about "protection of individual liberties".

In 2015, Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare will now use the plant for pharmaceutical production, hoping to employ former Sanofi staff. Accord Healthcare develops, manufactures, and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to around 60 countries globally.

Richard Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn said the departures show the council's inability to hold on to senior staff and expects further departures. Angela Scott thanked the trio for their "dedication and professionalism".

Martin crashed at this year's TT, and the Fireblade bike has had mechanical problems. Martin said he was quitting road racing but clarified that he has no plans to do anymore road racing on the Hondas this year. He didn't race at the North West 200 and will not compete in next month's Ulster Grand Prix because the bike won't be competitive. He wants to race classics and oddball stuff.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts. It is the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May, after he defeated President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost for the first time in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. Taraba is the only result still outstanding, while the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive. Elections were not held in seven states. The APC has made historic gains, relegating the once-powerful PDP to a regional party. The PDP failed to get a national spread of votes, doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The Independent National Electoral Commission (Inec) reported 66 violent incidents at polling stations. On Sunday, Inec also announced that the APC had retained power in Lagos state.

Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, accuses Olam and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of encouraging unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to haze caused by fires. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third party suppliers. Olam says it has a "very vigorous sourcing policy" with "zero tolerance for burning". Olam only agreed to release the names of its 14 suppliers on Monday. Temasek dismissed the allegations and explained that they "fully support no-burn policies for land clearance". Mighty also says Olam "bulldozes rainforests to establish monoculture palm oil plantations" in Gabon. Olam responded that its private-public partnerships in the country strove to be both responsible and transparent.
On August 27, 2016, a restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat at restaurants outdoors.

- Fernando Forestieri is questionable due to a knee injury.
- David Nugent may return after missing Monday's game.
- Jacob Butterfield hopes to be recalled after scoring in the last game.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the ban on YouTube because Google launched a Pakistan-specific version. The ban was imposed by the Supreme Court in 2012 after the film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded. Google has provided a process for blocking access to offending material, but government requests for removal will not automatically be granted and will be recorded in YouTube's Transparency Report.

Domenico Scala, head of Fifa's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is being asked to withdraw from the upcoming elections by LFA boss Musa Bility due to a potential conflict of interest as Scala shares nationality with presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Bility says he will go to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw. Scala excused himself from the 2015 elections for the same reason, as he shared nationality with candidate Sepp Blatter. However, Scala's spokesman says that there is no conflict of interest as there is no incumbent president in this election. The election to replace Blatter will take place in 18 days.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died in an explosion at Harford Attachments on Spar Road shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. They were working in a paint-spraying area. Evidence suggests there was a flashover explosion due to a build-up of toxic fumes and ignition causing a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until apologising to Caf for complaints lodged during this year's Nations Cup. Morocco were able to enter the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) overturned a ban on its participation. Morocco were punished in February after being replaced as 2015 Nations Cup hosts and were replaced by Equatorial Guinea. Tunisia was leading 1-0 in the 90th minute of their quarter-final against the hosts when they were awarded a penalty. Tunisia's 2017 participation seemed in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A while Morocco will Cape Verde, Libya and Sao Tome in Group F.

Following Chelsea's 3-1 victory over City, Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, while Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's part in the mass fracas. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, and Fernandinho will serve a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

England leveled the series against Pakistan with a win at Old Trafford. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, resulting in their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Alastair Cook made 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire at New Road starting on Friday before the third Test at Edgbaston gets under way on 3 August.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has named Rob Howley as part of his backroom team. Forwards coach McBryde assumes head coach responsibilities for the third time after leading Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The WRU will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team.

Hull won against Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. Austin scored a penalty in the sixth minute, but Snodgrass and Dawson scored in the second half for Hull. Hull lost Hernandez and Keane to injuries in the first half. Marshall made saves for Hull, and Clucas had a goalline clearance.

At 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, a motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor. The motorcyclist lived locally. The tractor driver was not injured. The B1191 was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle.

President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into abuse of power claims revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev said the move was illegal. EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn said the move put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis was sparked by covert recordings which appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder. Mr. Zaev has been releasing recordings since February 2015, accusing the government of wiretapping 20,000 people. The government denies the accusations and has accused Mr. Zaev of trying to "destabilise" the Balkan nation, a claim he rejects.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match against Bournemouth. Swansea want to quickly appoint a new boss, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis believes Swansea has not been the same since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, and that the 'Swansea Way' has been diluted. He believes the current squad is good enough to stay up.

Dagenham's loss to Orient, despite goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona, resulted in their relegation to the National League under manager John Still. Orient's victory keeps their play-off hopes alive. Interim manager Andy Hessenthaler said they need to win games if they're going to get into the play-offs. Still is committed to helping Dagenham gain promotion from the National League next season.

Steven Gerrard, the former Reds captain, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February. Klopp said he had a good long chat with Gerrard, who wants to be a manager in the future. Gerrard retired as a player in November after a 19-year career.

McManus scored early, followed by Forbes, giving Morton a quick lead. McAusland scored, bringing Alloa back within one. McManus scored again, and Johnstone added another goal, securing a comfortable win for Morton.

Ofsted found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham which have now closed. Anyone running illegal schools could face a jail term of up to 51 weeks. Ministers are also consulting on plans for more regulation of places teaching for more than 6 to 8 hours a week. A total of 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, have been visited as part of an investigation in recent months. The cases uncovered were likely to be the "tip of the iceberg" and children were at risk of being abused or radicalised. Any place where children are taught for more than 20 hours a week has to register as a school. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors whose job will be to investigate illegal schools. The education secretary has now asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools it has identified. The government consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. It comes ahead of a number of proposals to open the region's first whisky distillery since 1837. Lead distiller Kate Macinnes aims to capture the local flavour palette and Borders terroir. The gin distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site. The gin takes its name from Lilliard, the heroine of the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam died after Gary Green reversed a vehicle into him at Swithens Farm. Green was more than two times the legal driving limit, having consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer. Harry's mother said her family had been "changed forever". Green was jailed for 16 months and two weeks after admitting to failing to ensure the safety of others.

Uruguay striker Luis Suarez, 27, can now train and play in friendly matches. He will join Barcelona's training session on Friday, and his public presentation as a new Barcelona player will be held on Monday at the Camp Nou. The Cas ruling still prevents him from playing "organised" matches but now allows him to take part in all "football-related activities". His competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be at Real Madrid on 26 October in El Clasico. Suarez will now be available for Uruguay's friendlies against Japan and South Korea in September and Saudi Arabia the following month. Cas said preventing Suarez from taking part in any football activity was "excessive".

On March 18, 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna beat Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania and his wife, Neringa Kirliauskiene. They competed in a 380-metre course, hurdling over haystacks, scrabbling up a steep slope, and dodging water pistols. Rich and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

In October, the paper system for car tax discs will be scrapped and job roles will change. The new electronic system will allow people to pay by monthly direct debit. Due to the changes, there may be a reduction in the amount of refunds received. Any reduction in the number of people needed for these activities will be managed through redeployment to other growth areas of the business.

Hungary is facing pressure from the EU to withdraw three laws concerning asylum seekers, NGOs and higher education. The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls and critics say the education law could lead to the closure of Central European University. Hungary refuses to withdraw the laws, stating that they belong to national competence and that the EU should not interfere. Poland has pledged to veto any EU move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights.

Emma Watson will play Belle in the film, which will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Luke Evans will play Gaston, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and the star will play Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

A.A. Gill, a columnist for the Sunday Times since 1993, died this morning after being diagnosed with cancer last month. Gill said he had been "very lucky" in his life. His final column will be featured in tomorrow's Sunday Times. Gill was known for his wit, intelligence, and fearless writing. Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill overcame dyslexia to become a writer. He is survived by his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, and their two children, as well as two children from a previous marriage to Amber Rudd.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator after performing on stage in a Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika, a traditional symbol in Mongolia that pre-dates Hitler. Russian news reported that he was hit over the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, resulting in a coma that lasted about 10 days. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but called local press reports "distorted". According to a police spokesman, the suspect is a Russian diplomatic officer, and the case is under investigation.

On Monday, Plane Stupid protested the airport's expansion plans on the northern runway at 03:30 BST. The protesters have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area and will appear in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police said security at the airport would be reviewed.

Nick Selman's 101 led Glamorgan to a total of 220, with Aneurin Donald contributing 36. Matt Taylor and Craig Miles ensured regular wickets for Gloucestershire. Gloucestershire struggled in the evening gloom. Michael Hogan is leading Glamorgan due to Jacques Rudolph's neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, of Flint, was arrested in August by North Wales Police after he chatted online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Hughes admitted to planning to make a false report to the police so that officers would come to the scene and he would then shoot them. The threats were made on two occasions, late at night, while Hughes was drunk. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody pending sentencing next week.

After being reduced to 8-2, Surrey posted a score of 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes (90) sharing a stand of 130. Yorkshire's run-chase was undermined by a three-wicket burst in nine balls from Stuart Meaker. Yorkshire were all out for 236. Davies went on to hit a six and 10 fours before finally falling to Waite, who took 3-48 and also dropped a more difficult return chance offered by Foakes. Bresnan made 68 but was the last to go.

A 56ft converted trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed coastguards at 07:00 BST because a pump was unable to cope with incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew placed a pump and towed the vessel to Holyhead.
