Laura Muir told BBC Scotland that her veterinary medicine studies will prevent her from joining the Scotland team at next year's event on Australia's Gold Coast. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships. Muir says the World Indoor Championships in March are "potentially a target". Hellen Obiri won 5,000m gold in London. Muir's time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds was her new outdoor personal best.

Robbie Savage discusses Liverpool's decline since last season, attributing it to poor transfer choices and injuries to key players like Daniel Sturridge. He notes their struggles in scoring, defending, and set-pieces. Savage also talks about Steven Gerrard's physical and mental challenges in securing his future with Liverpool, especially after his costly slip against Chelsea last season. Savage predicts a win for Chelsea in the upcoming match.

A Â£45m facility will be built in Kilmarnock that will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. East Ayrshire Council will ask the McIlvanney family for permission to name the campus after William McIlvanney, a writer born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was an English teacher who later became a full-time writer in 1975. He is known for works such as the Laidlaw trilogy, Docherty, and The Big Man. He died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area of the town near the swimming pool was evacuated for most of the morning and early afternoon. Other residents nearby were advised to open windows, stay indoors near walls, and avoid going outside. An exclusion zone remains in force on the river while experts make safe the sea mine which was spotted on Monday. It is thought to be a British mine, dating from the 1940s or 1950s. The evacuation affected three streets, with wider safety advice issued to residents within 500m of the device. There was also an exclusion zone at sea of about half a mile, and small boat owners were told not to sail during the operation. Caledonian MacBrayne reported some disruption to ferry services, affecting sailings from Gourock and Rothesay. The evacuation had been a precautionary measure, and that there was no immediate danger to the community of Gourock. Due to the deterioration of the mine it was not possible to conclude how much explosive material it still contained and it was decided to move it to a safer place before dealing with it.

A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, which is £2m less than the amount allocated for the Rio Games. UK Sport has set Team GB a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals, and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Archery, fencing, weightlifting and wheelchair rugby have also missed out. Cycling has had its funding cut by more than £4m to £25.98m. Badminton is the only sport that earned a podium place in the summer to have its funding removed. Judo has had its funding increased slightly. Investment in the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020 is yet to be confirmed. £9m of the £345m total is still to be allocated.

A six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks will be built at East Cliff in Bournemouth, replacing three Victorian hotels. Councillors voted in favor of the development, stating it would help tourism. The site on Grove Road and East Overcliff Drive will get a 90-room hotel along with a nine-storey and seven-storey building, comprising 122 assisted-living apartments. Applicants The East Cliff Project LLP will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View hotels. English Heritage objected to the scale of the development, stating it would cause "severe harm" to the conservation area.

Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, was off-duty in Brecon when he was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter because he was not present during the attack. Vallely, 24, will be sentenced on 8 December. Pte Boyd's body was found by police in the early hours of 8 May. Pte Boyd was attacked outside a bar called The Cellar. CCTV footage showed Vallely punching, beating, and dragging Pte Boyd's body. Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge and was boasting he was the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. Det Supt David Guiney called the attack "a despicable act" that "shocked" the community. A family tribute described Pte Boyd as an "all-rounder" and said Vallely had created "a void in our family that will never be filled".

Andrew Travers left the authority by "mutual agreement" after voters were turned away from all 155 polling stations because their names were missing from the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily. Barnet Council apologised for the problems and later offered emergency proxy votes to residents who had been affected. The council's review will conclude by the end of May and the findings will be presented publicly to the General Functions Committee.

Josh Gillies scored a free-kick putting Gateshead ahead, but Sean Newton equalized with a set-piece. Ryan Bowman then scored a header, securing a 2-1 victory for Gateshead over Wrexham. Gateshead's manager, Malcolm Crosby, noted his team's improved passing in the second half, while Wrexham's manager, Gary Mills, expressed disappointment in his team's second-half performance.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 measures the social and economic welfare of those over 60 in 96 countries. Norway comes on top and the worst country is Afghanistan, followed by Mozambique.

OneWeb and Airbus are collaborating to create a network of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband access, with a focus on connecting every school. This project requires a shift to high-volume, low-cost satellite manufacturing using assembly line methods similar to car and plane factories, with a target of producing three units per shift at under a million dollars each. The first assembly line has been inaugurated in Toulouse, France, with additional lines planned for Florida. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April of the following year, with a larger launch campaign involving over 20 Soyuz vehicles to deploy satellites into orbit. OneWeb aims to have just under 300 satellites in place by the end of 2020/early 2021, over 600 a year later, and over 800 by the middle of the decade. OneWeb has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking additional loans. The company is registered in the UK's Channel Islands and is working with the UK Space Agency. OneWeb is committed to de-orbiting old satellites within two years and has included extra hardware for reliable de-orbiting, as well as an adapter for removal by a chase vehicle if necessary.

Mr. Swinney said the UK government's recent spending review placed "unprecedented pressure" on public expenditure in Scotland, but the UK government said Scottish ministers would have £390m more in spending available to them next year. Mr. Swinney is due to present his 2016-17 spending plans on Wednesday. The Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. Mr Swinney said schools, hospitals and the police service in Scotland would "not be sacrificed to the chancellor's austerity obsession". A spokesman for the UK government's Scotland Office said: "The Scottish government will have £390m more spending available to it next year, which rises to £750m if you include its own underspend. Labour's public services spokeswoman Jackie Baillie said: "Ahead of the most important budget since devolution, it's time John Swinney backed up his anti-austerity posturing with something real."

Many people with severe disabilities and their carers face challenges when leaving the house due to a lack of suitable toilet facilities. Standard accessible toilets are not sufficient for those who need assistance from two carers or a hoist. Recommendations are in place to support installing Changing Places toilets in larger buildings, but campaigners want these to be compulsory. Changing Places toilets have extra features and more space than standard disabled toilets. There are currently 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK. Making Changing Places toilets compulsory in larger complexes would provide clarity and ensure accessibility for those who need them.

A group of Italian consumers' organisations made a formal complaint to the European Commission accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's said it shared risks and rewards with its licencees. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the formal antitrust complaint. The European Commission said it would now study the submission and has the powers to launch an investigation if it believes the allegations are founded. The consumer organisations claim franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors because McDonald's makes them sign longer-than-average contracts and that licensees lease premises from the company at above market rates. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe. McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A #prayforjosh poster appeared in Holywood as part of a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The social media campaign began with Bangor Elim Church and went viral. A mystery donor paid for the sign. There has been a huge outpouring of support on Twitter.

The UK military buildings are being shaken up and regiments are being resettled. Brecon and Radnorshire Conservative MP Chris Davies condemned the closure of Brecon Barracks, which has been in Brecon since 1805. A specialist light infantry centre will be created at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Cawdor Barracks, Pembrokeshire will shut in 2024, while a storage depot at Sennybridge will go in 2025.

A House of Lords report reviews the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry due to Brexit. Fishing regions voted heavily to leave the EU, as the EU's Common Fisheries Policy has been characterized as a disaster for Britain. Brexit offers the chance to regain control over UK waters. The Lords say the fishing industry must not be marginalized in wider Brexit negotiations, but the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The report also points to the fact that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and the UK should ensure that total allowable catches and quotas should continue to be based on scientific advice. Many in the fishing industry still argue that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

Edward Snowden revealed that the NSA has access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data of individuals. The US government requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and the phone numbers of both parties on individual calls. Prism enabled "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major technology companies. The ways in which individual governments monitor citizen activity is secretive, and officials argue that preventing terrorism overrides protecting privacy. User data is often not stored in the same country as the users themselves. It is not known whether other governments around the world have been either aware of or involved in the use of Prism.

OpenAI, backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services, aims to focus its research on a "positive human impact", free from financial obligations. Concerns have been raised by scientists, including Mr. Musk and Stephen Hawking, that advances in AI could threaten humanity. OpenAI's website states the venture aims to "advance digital intelligence in the way that is most likely to benefit humanity as a whole, unconstrained by a need to generate financial return" and that AI "should be an extension of individual human wills...as broadly and evenly distributed as is possible safely".

L/Bdr Parkinson, who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26. Since then, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests, exceeding the site's limit of 5,000. His nomination stated that he lost his speech due to a brain injury, but has since recovered and now speaks unaided. He spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab, walks with crutches, raises money for military charities, and is a patron of Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, said the responses have been phenomenal and that Ben is buoyed up by the support. He has received hundreds of requests to visit places with the torch. A total of 8,000 people will carry the flame during its 8,000 mile, 70-day journey.

In 2011, the poverty rate was 15%, with 46.2 million Americans in poverty. The real median income of households dropped by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four in 2011 was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6%. The percentage of Americans lacking health insurance fell to 15.7% from 16.3%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old short-format specialist, moved from Somerset to the Red Rose in 2013, and his new deal ties him to the club until 2019. He has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. He will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. Bidders had until 23 January to register an interest in the former Devonport-based ships. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Viewings are set to take place in late February and March, with a final decision expected in the spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority wants to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler. Penny Mordaunt is keen to see at least one of them saved from the scrapyard, with a preference to go for the reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence has previously said it will "consider all options" for the frigates to ensure "best financial return for the taxpayer". The Type 22 frigate evolved into a powerful surface combatant with substantial anti-surface, anti-submarine and anti-aircraft weapons systems. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold as scrap for Â£3m.

Since 1987, racial and political tensions have caused instability and international isolation in Fiji. A coup in 1987 by indigenous Fijians overthrew the elected, Indian-dominated coalition, followed by another coup in 2000. These events harmed the economy and Fiji's international reputation. Continuing tensions led to a military takeover in 2006, Fiji's fourth coup in 20 years, and suspension from the Commonwealth in 2009. In 2012, the government agreed to hold free elections in 2014, and Fiji was re-instated as a Commonwealth member after the elections. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with indigenous Fijians now making up a small overall majority. The economy relies on sugar and tourism, but Fiji has been hampered by trade and budget deficits.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad said Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing Wednesday's deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, due to a shipment of weapons being attacked twice. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights claims 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in Aleppo in the last five days alone after barrels containing explosives and metal fragments were dropped by military helicopters, but Mr Mekdad insisted that they have never bombarded places with civilians. The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while the Observatory says fighting is still going on. The US said last week that so far only about 4% of the stockpile - 30 tonnes - had left the country. Russia has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. Mr Mekdad stressed: "Syria is committed to all its agreements, with the OPCW and the UN Security Council. We shall implement on time all our obligations."

The Booker Prize winner will be announced Tuesday night at London's Guildhall. This is the first year the prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others is the favorite to win. Howard Jacobson, a former winner, is on the shortlist, along with Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler and Richard Flanagan. The shortlisted authors each receive £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book.

PJS is appealing against an appeal court ruling which lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal, and if so, decide if it should be "allowed or dismissed". An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities by PJS, who argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The court judgement said PJS had "occasional sexual encounters" with AB, starting in 2009, including a three-way sexual encounter. In January, AB and CD approached the Sun On Sunday with the story. Lawyers for News Group Newspapers asked Court of Appeal judges to lift the ban because stories had been published in the US, Scotland and elsewhere where the injunction does not apply. On Monday, the judges ruled that PJS was now unlikely to be able to get a permanent injunction because details about the allegations were now "so widespread" that confidentiality had "probably been lost".

Fosse Park, near junction 21 of the M1, opened in 1989 and was bought in August for Â£345.5m. Plans are being prepared to improve parking and traffic congestion and the appearance of units. The new owners met with the council to clear up "potential planning questions". Two things the new owners want to address are parking and congestion issues around the park, as well as the quality of the common areas.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" was due for release in Malaysia on Thursday, but Disney said it was being held for a "review" of its content due to a "gay moment" in the film. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the screening with "a minor edit concerning a gay moment in the film". Homosexual activity is illegal in Malaysia. The live-action remake was granted a "P13 parental guidance classification". Local cinema chains have been offering refunds for customers who have purchased tickets in advance. The "exclusively gay moment" in the film involves LeFou, who tries to come to terms with feelings for Gaston. A Twitter user called the decision to review the film "stupid and laughable".

Landlords who let properties to more than three unrelated people need a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost £1,000, despite a fine of up to £20,000 for not having one. Southampton City Council estimated 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Mandatory licensing for HMOs nationally is aimed at houses of three storeys or more and occupied by five or more unrelated people. In Southampton, the licences affect properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (Designation 1) and in Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2). The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Enda Kenny and Micheál Martin hope to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government, but will not support a programme for government. Water charges are one of the main sticking points to reaching agreement. Following the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and the Labour Party got seven. No party was able to form a majority government and TDs have so far failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, travelling to Valencia, caught fire and passengers were evacuated to lifeboats and rescued by another ship. Three people were injured and taken to hospital. The fire broke out on Tuesday afternoon on one of the car decks, 27km from Mallorca. Several ships were sent to help, and the passengers and crew boarded the Puglia. The rescued passengers were on their way back to Palma de Mallorca. The Sorrento may sink and sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time. A full evacuation was called for due to the intensity of the fire.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs highlighted instances of people, including students, claiming to have voted twice, which is a criminal offense. They suggest that individual electoral registers should be better joined to identify duplicate entries. A record 46.8 million people were registered for the 8 June election, and 68.7% voted, the highest turnout since 1997. There were 2.9 million applications to register to vote in the six-week period after the snap poll was called. Concerns persist over duplicate applications due to the lack of direct link between electoral registers and the online registration service. Between December 1, 2016, and the 22 May deadline, about 4.9 million applications to vote were submitted, but the net increase was only 1.4 million, suggesting many duplicates. The watchdog said this caused administrative and financial burdens and should be addressed with clearer information on registration sites. The watchdog is calling for people registered in two seats to choose which one they will vote in. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote.

Lawrence Phillips, 40, a former NFL player, is believed to have killed himself early on Wednesday. Phillips played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers until 1999. After his NFL career, he was convicted of assault for driving his car into a group of teenagers and also of assaulting a former girlfriend. He was serving a term of more than 30 years and had been placed in a cell alone after being accused of killing his former cellmate, Damion Soward, 37. On Tuesday, a judge found that there was enough evidence to try Phillips in the death of Soward.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and the mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behaviour" by Brigadier Andrew Williams at an event in Chester. He is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to 1858. He joined the regiment in February 2014, has his own army number, gets paid to buy his rations, and takes his holidays on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. He has also helped switch on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory against Borussia Dortmund, moving closer to earning a place in the Champions League. Manager Jurgen Klopp inspired the team to overcome a 3-1 deficit by invoking the spirit of Istanbul 2005. Goals from Coutinho, Sakho, and Lovren completed the turnaround. Klopp has successfully instilled his identity on the team and fans, creating a special atmosphere at Anfield. Despite vulnerabilities, Liverpool's performance has boosted their confidence in the Europa League. Klopp has banned players from touching the "This Is Anfield" sign until they win something, as a sign of respect.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, Mr. Davis said the UK government would keep Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland up-to-date about negotiations and wants to hold monthly meetings to share analysis. Mr. Russell said transparency about UK government plans was needed and that the UK government has still not made its strategic intentions clear. The Scottish government will seek to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal.

Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr is physically examining Daisy, a clone and one of 13 cloned sheep on a farm owned by the University of Nottingham. Daisy is one of four cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly the sheep. The sheep are undergoing methodical tests to determine if cloned animals age normally and how healthy they are. The study is trying to determine if "age-memory" is transferred during the cloning process, potentially causing cloned animals to develop age-related diseases earlier. The original Dolly died at six-and-a-half, suffering from osteoarthritis. The study involves regular joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results of the study will be published next week.

Jockey John Gosden let the unbeaten 4-7 favourite race after he walked the course and she beat runner-up Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters and is headed to Chantilly next. Tasleet (14-1) took the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas. Shutter Speed brought a fifth Musidora win for both Gosden and Dettori. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in Thursday's Dante Stakes and will again walk the course before deciding whether he runs in the Derby trial.

The pound initially slipped against the dollar and euro, recovering in mid-afternoon trading before falling again. The "volatility index" hit levels last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound simply retreated to March levels. The pound was down 0.2% against the dollar at $1.4226. Against the euro, sterling was down 0.6% at â‚¬1.2605 and weakened by 1% against the Japanese yen to just over 151. Investors have been spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote have fallen. Two polls at the weekend put the Leave camp ahead, while betting firm Betfair said the implied probability of a vote to Remain had now fallen to 68.5% from almost 80% a week earlier. The markets were now on full Brexit alert. Sterling has shed more than 2% in two sessions to retrace its April lows. Worries about the economic impact of leaving the EU were also blamed for a big fall in Asian stock markets. Japan's Nikkei index closed 3.5% down, while Hong Kong's main index slid 2.5%. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1% at 6,044.9 points, with Lloyds Banking Group the biggest faller, down 4.2%. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage said that sterling had recently been strengthening and that a weaker pound was good for UK exporters.
The Iron are currently sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. Braintree's losing run extended to three games, but Cowley remained positive.

From April 2015, responsibility for planning decisions will shift to the councils themselves, meaning elected politicians will make planning decisions. Michael Corr believes this is a huge opportunity for local councils to develop their own community and development plans. Friends of the Earth warn that a strict code of conduct will have to be rigorously enforced to ensure fair and transparent handling of planning matters and are concerned about close relationships between developers and political parties. Some local politicians remain opposed to the move because they say it could deter donors worried about their personal security.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot twice in the shoulder and once in the left back leg, which vets had to amputate. Teenie was found injured by her owner Sarah Nisbett in Winchburgh. The Scottish SPCA is looking for the person responsible. The Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons last year, but a majority of responders opposed the plan.

Liverpool has signed Christian Benteke, making him their second most expensive signing, to a long-term contract. The club triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract after selling Raheem Sterling to Manchester City. Benteke has scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa since 2012. Benteke said he came to Liverpool to win trophies and be part of the manager's project. Liverpool struggled for goals last season and manager Brendan Rodgers added Benteke to revive the Reds' attack. Liverpool has also signed Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Paul Lambert believes Benteke will do well at Anfield. John Aldridge is excited to see Benteke lead the Liverpool forward line.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools, which looked at 671 state and independent schools, found that tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. There is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. In 9% of schools, there was an individual tablet device for every pupil. The highest use of tablet computers was within academy schools. Between 2014 and 2016, the number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers were particularly useful in helping boys and poorer pupils to learn to read. Within a sample of schools where every pupil has a tablet computer, a quarter of secondary pupils described themselves as internet "addicts". About 70% of five to 15-year-olds had access to a tablet at home.

The Growing Up in the City exhibition at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs of children's lives over 100 years, providing a social history of Liverpool. The photographs span from the 1880s to the 1990s and show how much life for a child has changed. The exhibition was put together by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History at the Museum of Liverpool. The exhibition is at the Museum of Liverpool until September 25.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals and could play against his old club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, and have won only one of their last six games.

A new law in Bolivia permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. The law also sets harsher punishments for violence against children, including a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The legislation reflects the needs of Bolivia and aims to balance reality with international treaties. More than 500,000 children in Bolivia work to supplement family income. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty. The ILO is studying the legislation to determine if it breaches international regulations on child labor.

After experiencing symptoms such as nausea and aches, the 50 year-old actress searched "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day. The cardiologist found a 99 percent blocked artery and inserted a stent. She revealed the heart attack was known as the "widow maker" and warned her readers to know the symptoms and call 911.

Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton at about 00:30 GMT after a fight at a party on Saturday evening. He was pronounced dead about an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and taken to a north London hospital. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder. Two boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A third, aged 14, is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized its patient diagnosis approach due to alarming cancer survival statistics. The changes included three routes: fast-track diagnosis for "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for symptoms GPs cannot diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for minor symptoms needing quick identification. The results have led to better survival rates and improved organization without overwhelming the system.

On March 31, 2014, Powys won the competitive bidding process to deliver the service in place of the OFT and will receive Â£170,000 a year to carry out the work. It will be able to issue warning and banning orders against agents acting dishonestly or breaching estate agent laws. People complaining about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will prosecute offenders if necessary, and will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the 1.3 million-strong workforce to help cover gaps in junior doctor rotas and GPs struggling with rising patient numbers. The Nuffield Trust highlighted examples of nurses filling in for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs. The report said that such moves made sense because of the changing nature of care, with much more stress on looking after people with long-term conditions. The Nuffield Trust admitted money would need to be set aside to ensure it happened. Unions warned against using it as a quick fix for problems in the NHS.

Following a crash at 03:00 GMT, Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot. The A36 road closure, which was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption to commuters and bus services. Investigations are under way into how the collision happened. First said that while parts of its services had resumed a normal schedule, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal.

NRW estimated that the lagoon would result in the deaths of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout annually. TLP disputed NRW's figures, stating they lacked a "clear scientific basis" and claimed NRW refused to share its methodology. TLP's modelling estimated a "worst case scenario" of 2% of all species of fish being killed. The Â£1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is being viewed as a test bed for larger versions around the coast. The UK government is considering the findings of a six-month review of the scheme's viability. The Welsh Government is "very supportive" of the scheme. NRW strongly disagreed with TLP's criticism and said they have the "utmost confidence" that it is the best evidence available.

Arlene Foster announced the development of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). The body will provide strategic leadership for marketing activities. Michelle O'Neill welcomed the announcement but said the plans could have implications for other organizations.

On Saturday afternoon, the public can plant trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley. The Woodland Trust organized the event as one of four new woods being created across the UK. The aim is to plant millions of native UK trees to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. In Brackfield Wood, the plan is to plant 40,000 trees in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The charity is providing the saplings, and has advised volunteers to wear welly boots or "stout footwear".

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate on Thursday for Someone Else's Skin, which is the first in a series of novels featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome. US author Sara Paretsky, who created detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honour. Ann Cleeves said Sara Paretsky "really changed the way that readers thought about female writers" and set up Sisters In Crime, an organisation to support female crime writers around the world.

Mitch Santner, who broke his finger in his second game for the county in 2016, will rejoin the Rapids after June's ICC Trophy in England. Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season in August.

In 2008, Barry Pring, 47, died in Kiev after being hit by a speeding car while hailing a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating the car had stolen license plates and did not brake. A close friend stated he had "no reasonable doubt" that Barry was murdered. His family believes it was a staged hit and run. They met online in 2006 and married in 2007. His mother stated that Ms. Ziuzina was a lap dancer and stripper, not a teacher as she had claimed. The inquest heard Ms. Ziuzina sold her husband's Range Rover, contents from his flat and moved funds from his bank account. Computer records revealed "she was having an affair with a Ukrainian man". Witnesses described the killing "as a deliberate act". The Ukrainian police relaunched it in 2011 as a murder inquiry.

Charlie, from Merseyside, needs to fly to Seattle for T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital because the last transplant failed and there is no option left for treatment in the UK. An anonymous donor has paid for his treatment, which Charlie's parents are extremely grateful for. The treatment will start as soon as possible.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent third-party software from stealing intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. The security facility remains an opt-in choice, requiring a four-digit code to be entered after the username and password on a new device. A 14-character recovery key can be used if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple will now notify the account owner via email when a back-up starts downloading. One expert suggests that Apple should make the two-factor authentication the default option. Apple plans to encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

Dan Groves said the "finer points" of a deal which could see Wright buy 20% of Billericay are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Billericay are eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Wright played non-league football for a succession of clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay have recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Mr. Ashley was asked to give evidence about the treatment of his workers after a BBC investigation into his company's warehouse working practices. Mr. Wright's letter states that the committee will be keeping the treatment of low-paid workers under review. Mr. Ashley has until March 21 to respond to the letter. The committee has offered alternative dates to Mr. Ashley, but he has not accepted them. If Mr. Ashley fails to reply and agree to attend, the committee reserves the right to take the matter further. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for comment.

The report "Putin. War" was completed by Ilya Yashin and colleagues of murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. The report accuses Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, alleging that Russian soldiers and equipment secured victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. The report presents evidence of volunteer soldiers directed by Russian generals and calculates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles. The opposition accuses Putin of directing the war to boost his popularity, while many Russians find the country's involvement in eastern Ukraine acceptable.

Craig Nelson, 34, was found at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. He died as a result of head injuries. A man, 41, and a woman, 23, were arrested in Sheffield and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones complained that he didn't see the Article 50 letter before it was published, which he found unacceptable because the devolved administrations have been treated with a lack of respect. Alun Cairns responded by saying that the UK government needs to act in the interests of the whole of the UK. Mrs. May mentioned in the letter that the UK government will consult fully on which powers should reside in Westminster and which should be devolved to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It is expected that the outcome of this process will be a significant increase in the decision-making power of each devolved administration. The identity of the powers the UK government wants to see devolved is a mystery.

On Friday night, two cars were damaged in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin said he was "appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community". The PSNI also appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, who founded American Apparel, was ousted last year because of employee complaints and accusations of misuse of company funds. The board said it did not expect him to return to the firm. The court filing documents evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts. American Apparel was granted a restraining order preventing him from making any negative statements about the company and from trying to get board members removed.

The basketball game between Great Britain and Greece will be available on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Three members of the Greek team will be missing, giving GB a chance to win. This is Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017 in Istanbul, Turkey, in September. After the game against Greece, they will travel to Poland for a four-team tournament.

The author was asked by a producer to cover the new iPhone, which was difficult because it was not available to the public. The author remembered an offer to interview Apple’s marketing chief Phil Schiller, who allowed the author to look at the iPhone before the interview. The author used it for a news piece, leading to some complaints about undue prominence. The author defended the coverage, comparing it to the Model T Ford. The author reflects on how the iPhone has radically changed photography and other activities, with its attractive user interface making people want to do more than talk and text. The author feels grateful to have witnessed the beginning of the mobile connected era.

Cats near Victor Avenue, in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have ingested a toxic substance. Seven-month-old Meereen died on Monday. Three other cats in the area have died in the last seven days, while another cat died two weeks ago. Meereen's owner found her foaming from the mouth and trying to be sick and was confirmed to have consumed antifreeze. The RSPCA is appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals were stored safely and to make sure there are no antifreeze leaks from cars.

Even though the Syriza government is set to agree to austerity and liberalisation measures, there are no demonstrations in Athens. Greek resorts are teeming with tourists, with the Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. The lack of protests may be due to the calm before the revelation of how much Alexis Tsipras has conceded to obtain €86bn of new credit from the eurozone and IMF. Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity, and Greece is suffering from monetary austerity due to the continued partial closure of banks. The new bailout will only hold if Tsipras can offer hope of better times ahead, requiring creditors to ease the burden of Greece's debts.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell, will briefly return to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes. Barbara's character, Peggy, reappeared to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in the spring. Kemp played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006. Grant arrived in 1990 along with brother Phil and was involved in family dramas. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins said Grant Mitchell is an EastEnders legend and is returning home to say goodbye to his mother and be reunited with his brother.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked Alice Ruggles. Alice's parents knew Dhillon was responsible when police informed them of her death. Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years. Alice's parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking.

EDF, a French firm, approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, with one third of the cost provided by Chinese investors. The UK government has launched a further review of the project, causing EDF's chief executive to cancel a trip to Hinkley Point and raising concerns about Anglo-French relations. Critics cite environmental damage, escalating costs, and the involvement of foreign governments as potential issues. The Nuclear Industry Association urges a quick government decision to avoid energy supply problems, while the EEF manufacturers' organisation views the delay as a blow. Hinkley Point C is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity. Concerns about EDF's financial capacity and internal opposition to the project have also been noted, with one board member resigning and another leaving earlier in the year. The project timeline includes government proposals for nuclear energy in Jan 2006, construction approval in Mar 2013, agreement on electricity pricing in Oct 2013, investment agreement with China in Oct 2015, and a postponed government decision in July 2016.

The newly-designed divorce application form for England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse committed adultery with, though the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name them. Family lawyers say that involving a third party adds conflict and complexity. The guidance on the form highlights that it is "not normally necessary" to name the person. If the person is named, they become part of the court case. In 2015, there were just over 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales, with adultery being the reason for 12,148 of them.

Ministers are believed to be placing too much emphasis on the environment at the expense of trees grown for timber. Confor warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be replanted to meet needs. The Welsh government wants a balance between the environmental, the economic and the social in how forestry is developed and wants Wales to be known for its high quality woodlands. Martin Bishop, of Confor, believes the emphasis on environmental aspects is seen as "sexier" than commercial forestry and that the current system is too bureaucratic for creating new woodland areas.

A boy was badly injured after being struck in Coatbridge. Emergency crews were called to Bank Street near Langloan Primary School at about 16:40. He was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital, in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to the men of the Arctic Convoys. The convoys consisted of vessels which travelled from Britain to northern Russia to resupply the Soviet Union during World War II. By May 1945, the Arctic route had claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels and more than 3,000 men died. The Foreign Office initially did not allow Russia to honour the veterans as it broke the rules on foreign medals, but later allowed an "exception to the rules" and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal is awarded to sailors who have displayed courage in the course of defending Russia or its interests.

In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to do unpaid work. HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in getting offenders to start their work, and too many were let off if they did not attend. Inspectors looked at 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders and the report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement. The Ministry of Justice said it was acting on the report's recommendations.

A newspaper called a comedian a "hypocrite" because he campaigns for economic and political "revolution" to help poorer people, yet he lives in a luxury home. The comedian was asked about his own accommodation by a TV reporter and he called the Channel 4 News journalist "a snide", before walking off. The comedian didn't reply to Newsbeat to see if he was really going to take legal action against The Sun and its owner Rupert Murdoch, though he has been tweeting about The Sun and it's accusations of hypocrisy - using the hashtag #TheSunLogic. The comedian says that he has to change as an individual and part of that will be sharing wealth, though without systemic change, that will be a sweet, futile gesture.

Dr. Venter mapped the human genome, created a synthetic life form called Synthia, and determined the complete genome of Haemophilus influenzae. Born in 1946, he served as an orderly in Vietnam, which inspired him to become a doctor. He realized the importance of decoding genes and developed methods to speed up the process. In 1992, he left the NIH and set up a private research institute. In May 1998, he announced the formation of Celera Genomics to crack the entire human genetic code in three years. In 2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute. He also collected life forms from the ocean to better understand the evolution and function of genes and proteins.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches had tried food at school that they had not tried at home. Half of parents questioned said their children had asked for foods they had eaten at school to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas and spinach were among the least popular. The School Food Trust commissioned the research after a survey suggested some parents gave their children packed lunches because they thought they were too fussy to eat anything else. About four in 10 primary school children in England now eat school lunches, slightly more than in secondary schools. More children in Scotland eat school lunches - about 46%.

Morata, 23, is playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real. Real had an option to buy him back for up to 30m euros (£23m). He scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in back-to-back Champions League finals. He scored 10 goals for Real.

Wilson, age 30, was released from Championship side Forest in May, where he had rejoined in August 2013 from Celtic for £2.5m. He made 51 appearances in his second spell. He previously played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco is disposing of its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, and about 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees are to transfer to the new business as part of the deal. Tesco will loan the new business around Â£80m. It will cost Tesco Â£150m to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand. Yucaipa is a Los Angeles based private equity company and will be taking over the business.

He initially experienced racial abuse, overcame that, and after briefly considering representing France, is now targeting a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. A special guide is available for those interested in learning how to get into martial arts.

From the late 1960s/early 1970s to the late 2000s, the ice fields in the French Alps decreased from 375 sq km to about 275 sq km. A survey by Marie Gardent and colleagues assessed roughly 600 glaciers and found an average loss of some 26% over the last 40 years. The greatest losses have been seen in the southern sectors. The glacier retreat is less important in the northern Alps than in the southern Alps.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers to date and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. Iceland are ranked one place above the Scots at number 20 in the world. The outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September is likely to decide who tops the group. Evans is one of 12 players in the current 20-strong squad who play outside Scotland. Evans believes the benefits of having more players in the world's top leagues benefits the national team as they close in on a first major finals.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England on Friday following a complaint from a woman in south London, who alleged harassment over a two-year period. Mr. Campbell, a blogger and campaigner for Scottish independence who launched the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011, was released on bail. He said the complaint concerned some tweets and insisted they were not threatening, accusing the media of "innuendo" designed to encourage "speculations". He has been bailed, pending further inquiries, to a date in mid-September.

Peta wants the Jolly Fisherman mascot to be replaced with a modern animal-friendly version, suggesting a fish with the slogan Skegness - A Happy Plaice. The mayor of Skegness said all suggestions were welcome but did not think there would be much support for axing Jolly. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was commissioned in 1908 and has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. Dawn Carr, of Peta, said Jolly "evokes images of cruelty to animals" and that Peta's suggestion would give the resort an opportunity to rebrand itself as a progressive holiday destination. Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, said the Jolly Fisherman was loved by adults and children alike and that if it isn't broken, they won't try and fix it.

Georgia scored first with a try from Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland quickly took the lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg. Hamish Watson extended the lead after half-time, and Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia. Hogg then scored again, finishing off a counter-attack. Moray Low received a yellow card. Ali Price and Rory Hughes assisted Hogg in scoring his second and Scotland's sixth try. Vern Cotter, Scotland's head coach, noted the good first half and the team's ability to score points when needed.

Widnes beat Castleford, with tries from multiple players including Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge. Cas loanee Paddy Flynn responded against his parent club with two tries early in the game, and a hat-trick score later on. Widnes scored more tries and took a significant lead. Despite three Cas tries, Widnes held on to win. Widnes moved to seventh place, while Castleford remains in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, 37, was released after a US review panel concluded he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been at the US facility in Cuba since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, a charge he denies. He boarded a Kuwaiti government plane on Wednesday morning US time and now faces at least a year at a militant rehabilitation centre in Kuwait, according to the terms of the release. Mr Odah's release brings down the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. Thousands attended the early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and up to 400 people took part in a parade before the wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. A service was also held at Westminster Abbey. The first time Anzac Day was commemorated in the capital was when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service in 1916, a year after the Anzac landings at Gallipoli.

Clarkson, 30, joined Premiership Well in July for a second spell and could debut for St Mirren in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season. Clarkson has been capped twice for Scotland in 2008 and has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level. St Mirren are eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of Alloa.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. The new owners will honour current agreements and the current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews will continue under the new ownership. The new owner wishes to restore Bernard Matthews to its former position as a highly profitable business by greater investment, cost savings and utilising the present spare capacity at Bernard Matthews to process chicken and not just turkeys.

The council held a meeting to discuss problems with the new vessel. The Cowes crossing will be free until July 2nd. The council ordered a review of the project by auditors, after a "frustrating and disappointing start" to the ferry. Since launching late on May 14, the chain ferry has broken down, run aground, and been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to "training issues." Cars have also been damaged. Compensation for local businesses is up for discussion. Electrical problems have been rectified, ramp extensions were authorized, and groundings were an issue with seamanship, which has been resolved.

A House of Lords report reviews the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry due to Brexit. Fishing regions voted heavily to leave the EU, as the EU's Common Fisheries Policy has been characterized as a disaster for Britain. Brexit offers the chance for the UK to regain control over UK waters; however, the industry might be a low priority for the government, as it only produces a half of one percent of GDP. Most commercial fish stocks are in waters shared between the UK and other EU coastal states, and the vast majority of UK fish are exported, mainly to the EU. The report says a successful industry needs continued market access, but that access may come at a price, as EU member states may demand more access to UK waters. The report also points to the fact that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit. If Britain leaves the EU, the CFP framework will fall away, raising the potential of four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. The EU announced agreement on new quotas under the CFP, and representatives from the industry said they believed this augurs well for the future of British fishing outside the EU.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting images to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014 and was put on the sex offenders register earlier this year. He has now been removed from his profession's register following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing. The Dumfries Sheriff Court heard that most of the images he downloaded were of young boys partially dressed in erotic poses with no sexual activity. He was also ordered to take part in a special programme for sex offenders. The panel found him unfit to teach and removed him from the professional register and is prohibited from applying to re-register for a period of two years.

Following a fire on March 2nd on Duncan Street, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. The fire service said the firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law. Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the premises nine times in the last 12 months. The fire service raised concerns to the EA in February over the impact a fire could have. The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit, and subject to any appeal, the revocation takes effect on 7 August. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria missed the Wednesday deadline to hand over its entire stockpile of chemical weapons. According to Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad, Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons and that a shipment of weapons came under attack twice on its way from Damascus to the port of Latakia. Mekdad described US Secretary of State John Kerry's recent condemnation of the government's use of barrel bombs in the city of Aleppo as "absolutely unacceptable". The Syrian government denied reports that rebels had seized most of Aleppo's central prison, while the Observatory says fighting is still going on. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, and the US said last week that about 4% of the stockpile had left the country. Russia has said Damascus should complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March.

England won against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Pakistan will play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is asking pensioners, their friends, and their families to share their experiences of residential care. This evidence will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies, as part of Ms. Rochira's review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Care Forum Wales supports the aims of the review but is disappointed that the commissioner has not included a provider expert on the main advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, former Dons midfielder and player-manager at Arbroath since 2010, replaces Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Derek McInnes chose Sheerin after "a comprehensive process". Arbroath chairman John Christison appreciated Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s and guided Arbroath to their first national trophy in their history by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Following Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Saturday's match against Bournemouth. Swansea want to quickly appoint a new boss, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Curtis believes Swansea have lost their way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, with frequent management changes diluting the 'Swansea Way'. He reminds new signings of the club's history and the importance of staying up.

Biologist Dr. Venter mapped the human genome, created a synthetic life form called Synthia, and sequenced genomes from microbes in the sea. Born in 1946, he served as an orderly in Vietnam, which inspired him to become a doctor. During his medical training, he excelled in research and worked at the US National Institute of Health. In 1992, he left NIH and set up a private research institute, The Institute for Genomic Research. In May 1998, he announced the formation of Celera Genomics to crack the entire human genetic code in three years. In 2006, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships are low quality and too short compared to other European countries. A study found that fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 apprenticeships starting in England every year are rated at level three, which is equivalent to A-level. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, and that the majority of these should be at level three for at least three years. The Department for Education says apprenticeships are being reformed to "drive up standards".

The Briton, Storey, finished more than two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland. Storey can win a 17th title in Saturday's road race and is targeting further Paralympic success at next year's Games in Rio de Janeiro. Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, 11 gold, eight silver and three bronze medals in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 Games in London and has now won 21 world titles across both sports. Storey began her sporting career in the pool, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before switching to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Conference due to financial issues, despite a dramatic final-day escape. Chester has been reinstated as a Conference Premier club, taking Hereford's place. Hereford's debt to football creditors totaled £148,000, and the Conference extended the payment deadline three times, but the club failed to meet it. Tommy Agombar took over the club last week, but could not make the deadline. The club also owes over £70,000 to clear the latest PAYE tax demand.

James Milner, age 30, formerly of Manchester City, earned 61 caps for England after his debut in 2009. He was in two World Cups and two European Championships. Milner holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 caps after his first appearance in 2004. He scored one international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova at the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge following an illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directed the academy across six continents for some 30 years. He was also the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping, and his family is still waiting for a place for him at a special school. In September, the family was told that all the special schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full to capacity. The family has now been told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school and the hope is that their son will be able to start there in the next few weeks. The Education Authority said they were "currently reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and is endeavouring to ensure that places are available close to where the children reside" and that this work is ongoing and is designed to assist with the placement of children with effect from 2016.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) has made a takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade "as a rugby venue". County has a lease to use the ground until 2023 and primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be put to a vote on May 9. County agreed to a 10-year lease in 2013. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. County is two points clear of League Two relegation with two games remaining.

Last weekend, the country was declared free of the virus that killed almost 4,000 people in the country over the past 18 months. The Ebola crisis came to Sierra Leone in 2014. During the crisis, education was provided to over 10,000 people in their languages, support was given to 11,000 people with food and other items, and an Ebola treatment unit was created.

Around 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs risked being auctioned to pay off the pottery firm's pension debt, but a public fundraising campaign hit its target in a month. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The Wedgwood Museum inherited Waterford Wedgwood plc's pension bill after the firm collapsed in 2009. In 2011 a high court judge ruled its collection could be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund.

Dan Groves said the "finer points" of a deal which could see Wright buy 20% of the club are yet to be released. The Sun reported that the 30-year-old will become a club director. Wright played non-league football for a succession of clubs, including Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay have recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he was "comfortable" investing £10,000 a week. The club signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, at the start of March.

Blackpool and Colchester United match ends in a 1-1 draw. Jamille Matt scored for Blackpool in the 12th minute and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester. Sean Murray from Colchester was shown a red card.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is planned to be the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, as the centrepiece of a "merchant city" development. The power station closed in 2013 after more than 40 years in operation. The Â£1bn development will feature a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. Building could start in 2018. The oil-fired Fawley Power Station was commissioned in 1971 and was capable of powering one million homes. The 300-acre site was sold to Fawley Waterside developers in 2016.

The 23-year-old Latham earned GB's second medal, a bronze, at the Hong Kong championships. Adrian Teklinski of Poland won gold, and Lucass Liss of Germany got silver. In other events, GB's men's team pursuit was beaten to the bronze medal by Italy, Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and GB's women's team pursuit finished fifth. Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell, will briefly return to EastEnders for Barbara's final episodes. Barbara's character, Peggy, reappeared to tell her son Phil that her cancer had returned and will die from the disease in the spring. Kemp played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006. He is returning to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time. Grant Mitchell arrived in 1990 and was involved in family dramas.

Sadio Mane scored twice as Spurs were defeated at Anfield. Pochettino said it is difficult to fight for the Premier League if they lack the desire to win and that it would be a big problem if Chelsea go 12 points clear. Spurs have only won twice on the road since September 24. Danny Murphy said he couldn't believe what he was watching and that Spurs should have stuck with playing with a back three.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts. It is the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since military rule ended in 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on 29 May, after he defeated President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. Taraba is the only result still outstanding, while the election in Imo state was declared inconclusive. Elections were not held in seven states.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, HebCelt, is taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July. Visitors can use an app to trigger online information from signs and posters, including videos and band interviews. The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean are among this year's acts. The message on the app will be updated, allowing people to instantly access information and interviews, buy tickets and also get a taste of the festival wherever they are.

Park View and Nansen Primary, both Birmingham academies rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running the schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. According to Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw, "a culture of fear and intimidation has taken grip" in Birmingham schools.

Vinnie Barker died in July 2012, five months after an eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Honey Rose, 35, is charged with gross negligence manslaughter for allegedly failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution argues that Vinnie's death was preventable if Ms. Rose had done her job properly.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, set up meetings between a woman and a man he found through an adult website, and filmed them having sex. He sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing the woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with the man between 10 September, 2013 and 17 September the following year and was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to look at sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner on 25 December, 2014. He was placed on the sex offenders register. The judge said that Weatherhogg had been assessed as posing "a moderate risk" of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in Greater Noida, with Stuart Thompson hitting 56 and Gary Wilson (41 no) and captain William Porterfield (39) adding valuable runs. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs to spare, with Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47) contributing. The second T20 will be at the same venue on Friday. Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza (2-23) was the only bowler to take more than one wicket. Boyd Rankin is out of the T20s due to a back problem but is expected to return for the five ODIs against Afghanistan, starting on 15 March.

Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m. Neymar will have cost the club £106.8m, including wages, agents fees, and tax. Sandro Rosell resigned as Barcelona president following accusations he misappropriated money. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence against Barcelona to continue investigations into the transfer. Barcelona made a complimentary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances for Barcelona this season, as well as netting three in seven Champions League matches.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK detectives went to Thailand to review the investigation into their murders and will compile a report and update the families. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are alleged to have confessed to the killings and are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the police investigation, and the UK police visit came after the Thai Prime Minister agreed that British officers could travel to Thailand. Post-mortem examinations found Mr. Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Ms. Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA found on Ms. Witheridge matched samples taken from the suspects.

The Scots have won all five qualifiers to date and host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. Iceland are also unbeaten after four wins from four. The outcome of Friday's contest and the return fixture in Reykjavik on 20 September likely to decide who tops the group. Evans is one of 12 players in the current 20-strong squad who play outside Scotland.

Apple has taken action to prevent third-party software from stealing intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud by introducing an extra security step that requires a four-digit code to be entered on new devices. This security feature remains an opt-in choice, but experts suggest it should be the default option. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access to the account if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple will now notify the account owner via email when a back-up starts downloading, regardless of whether two-factor authentication is enabled. Apple plans to encourage people to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

UKIP spent £2,956,737, while the Tories spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, and Labour spent £1,027,339. The figures cover the campaign period from 23 January to polling day, 22 May. UKIP's campaign spending works out at 68p for each vote, Labour 26p per vote, the Conservatives 79p and the Lib Dems £1.45. The Green Party spent £534,249 on its campaign - 43p for each vote. Including the SNP's £267,372, the six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning. All but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has cancelled his Barrow contract to join their National League rivals and could play against his old club on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Nicholson says Anderson is the leader-type he has been after, and Keating is young and hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, and have won only one of their last six games.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Many Clouds had shown symptoms of post-race ataxia in the past, which had seen him over-heat and "wobble" on his feet, but the horse had never collapsed before, and had shown no symptoms of post-race ataxia on Saturday. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime".

Tricia Marwick was emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and Mr. Salmond bid farewell to the parliament. Ms. Marwick, Mr. Salmond, and Mr. McNeil are stepping down as MSPs ahead of the election on May 5. Mr. Salmond repeated his belief that Scotland was "not divided, but diverse" and welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood. Mr. McNeil warned that Holyrood had things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system. Annabel Goldie is also bowing out of Holyrood.

Emma Watson will play Belle in the film set to be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Dan Stevens will play the Beast, Luke Evans will co-star as Gaston, and Josh Gad will play LeFou. Kevin Kline will play Maurice, and the star will play Mrs. Potts. Bill Condon will direct the movie, which begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will reveal its intentions at a meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST. Ninety-six football fans were fatally injured in the 1989 stadium disaster. Last year, new inquests concluded the fans had been unlawfully killed. In January, files of evidence relating to 23 suspects were referred to the CPS to decide whether charges should be brought. Relatives have been invited to a private meeting in Warrington, where they will be informed of the decisions by Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS.

Chelmsford Prison has had "numerous incidents" of packages being hurled over the wall. According to a former inmate, the jail is "notorious" for being "flooded" with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. A woman who lives near the prison said she had witnessed packages being thrown over the wall "four times in two weeks." A former inmate claimed drones were used to fly contraband goods, but the Ministry of Justice said there was no evidence of drones at the Chelmsford site. People who smuggle packages over prison walls could be jailed for up to two years.

- Sylvia Blackburn, 72, suffered serious head injuries outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, last December.
- Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, said he had been blinded by the setting sun.
- He accepted he had struck Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving.
- Mrs Blackburn is now being treated in residential care.
- Mr Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light.
- Mrs Blackburn, a lollipop lady for 20 years, had been on duty in Bedford Road as pupils left school.
- Prosecutor Sally Mealing-McLeod said traffic in the other direction had stopped, but the defendant did not, and hit her.
- Mr Wright said he could not remember if the traffic lights were red or green and that he was totally blinded by the sun.
- The court heard the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Mr Wright's eyes.
- The trial continues.
